Summary:
The patient is a 73-inch-old individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of multi-lumen start on 02/23/2177 at 04:18 PM and arterial line start on 02/23/2177 at 09:02 PM. The patient's overnight events include starting on milrinone, which caused pressure drops, so dopamine was started instead. The patient's urine output started to pick up, but they experienced excessive bleeding due to supratherapeutic PTT. The patient has no known drug allergies. The last doses of antibiotics administered were cefipime on 02/23/2177 at 10:12 PM and metronidazole on 02/24/2177 at 04:03 AM. The patient is currently on dopamine infusion at 5 mcg/kg/min and furosemide (Lasix) at 9 mg/hour. Other ICU medications include furosemide (Lasix) given at 12:24 AM on 02/24/2177. Other medications, medical and family history, review of systems, and flowsheet data are unchanged from admission except as noted below.

Flowsheet data as of 02/24/2177 at 06:41 AM shows vital signs with a temperature of 35.3 degrees Celsius (95.5 degrees Fahrenheit), current temperature of 35 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 93 bpm within a range of 68-102 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 64/37 mmHg to 132/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 5 inspiratory movements per minute within a range of 0-18, oxygen saturation of 97% on aerosol-cool face tent, and atrial fibrillation as the heart rhythm. The patient's height is 73 inches, central venous pressure (CVP) is 7 mmHg within a range of 7-21 mmHg, total input is 1630 mL including 339 mL of IV fluids, total output is 777 mL including 182 mL of blood products, and urine output is 777 mL including 182 mL. The patient is receiving respiratory support with an oxygen delivery device and has an arterial blood gas (ABG) result of //19/. Physical examination findings include peripheral vascular assessment, skin assessment, and neurologic assessment, all of which were not assessed. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) at 17.8 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hct) at 30.7%, platelet count (Plt) at 130 K/uL, creatinine (Cr) at 2.5-2.6 mg/dL, blood glucose levels ranging from 120-199 mg/dL, and other lab values including PT/PTT/INR, ALT/AST, alkaline phosphatase/T bilir

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of afib.
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF: HF was diagnosed [**9-14**], echo during this
   admission with worsened EF to 25%. This is thought to be [**1-7**]
   arrhythmias. Pt had difficulting with diuresis on the floor due to
   hypotension. Initial cause of HF is unclear, pt had a dilated heart. Pt
   also has pulmonary HTN which may be [**1-7**] his OSA. In prior studies his
   PA systolic pressure was estimated at 60+. Clinically, his exam is more
   c/w right than left heart failure. He likely has some Left heart
   failure, which is contributing to his edema on CXR and small oxygen
   requirment.
   - lasix gtt for now, titrate to UO 100/hr
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - continue metolazone for now
   - may need milrinone to increase BP if not able to tolerate gtt
   - CV tomorrow (see below)
   - once no longer in afib, would repeat echo to better assess EF
   - strict I's, O's
   - will restart ACE once renal function improves
   - hold BB until HF more stable
   - continue to hold home norvasc
   - continue ASA 81mg
   - place A-line for better BP monitoring
   .
   # Atrial fib/ventricular ectopy: Likely contributing to his worsening
   HF. Pt does appear to tolearte being in afib. Likely will benifit from
   cardioversion. Pt was subtheraputic on his coumadin so will need TEE
   - heparin gtt
   - cont amio
   - NPO at midnight for CV tomorrow, will need to page TEE fellow in AM
   .
   # LE ulcers: Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridment in future. WBC was elevated and temp was lower, so abx were
   brodened from cipro cefepime.
   - will continue vanco/cefepime/flagyl for now
   - f/u blood cx results
   - vascular recs regarding possible debridement
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Cr/GFR was at baseline on admission,
   now worsened in setting of diuresis and poor forward flow. Prior to his
   admission in [**9-13**] baseline Cr was 1.7, range seems to have been
   1.5-2.0.
   - monitor with diuresis
   - renally dose meds
   - will check vanco trough in AM
   - renal recs appreciated
   - may benifit from UF, but will require pressors
   .
   # AMS: had a AMS this AM. [**Month (only) 11**] have been secondary to low BP vs
   infection induced delerium. UA shows possible UTI. Pt had abx adjusted
   this AM. AMS may also be from OSA, however, pt refuses bipap
   - will monitor urine and blood cx
   - continue abx
   .
   # OSA: pt refuses bipap, venous ABG shows CO2 renention. This may
   expain his sleepiness.
   - consider trying a nasal bipap, unsure if pt has tried this type
   .
   # L pleural effusion: Likely transudative in setting of CHF. Small and
   stable on cxr [**2-23**]
   - will monitor
   - if enlarges or pt is febrile, consider a dx tap
   .
   # Ulcerative Colitis: Pt without current sx. Pt is on 20mg prednisone
   qday (normally Q48 hrs at home).
   - continue steriods for now, while pt is having transient hypotension,
   once improved will change back to home dose
   .
   # Tophaceous Gout: Diffuse tophi on exam.
   - continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol is 150 daily
   - holding home colchicine for now
   - on increased steriod dose
   .
   # Anemia: likely related to CKD, was on EPO at [**Hospital1 **]
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: chronic, s/p eval with negative HIT Ab, see last
   d/c summary.
   - will monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continuing home dose, TSH normal, total T4 low, but
   pt has been on amio (unsure if level was checked before or after it was
   started)
   - continue current dose
   - consider rechecking thyroid labs
   .
   # DMII: stable
   - Lantus 18qhs
   - humalog SSI
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure. He has been admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management of his conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute-on-chronic CHF: The patient's worsening heart function and fluid overload increase the risk of acute-on-chronic CHF exacerbation, leading to further pulmonary edema, hypotension, and respiratory distress.
2. Atrial fibrillation/ventricular ectopy: The patient's AF and ventricular ectopy can worsen his heart failure and increase the risk of thromboembolic events such as stroke.
3. Chronic kidney disease (CKD): The patient's CKD can progress further due to the ongoing renal insult from diuresis and poor forward flow. This may lead to an increase in serum creatinine levels and a decline in renal function.
4. Leg ulcers: The patient's leg ulcers are at risk for infection and potential surgical debridement. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started to cover possible bacterial infections.
5. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's known pulmonary hypertension may worsen due to

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and multiple comorbidities. The patient presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation (AF).

The patient's current medical conditions and potential complications include:
1. Bleeding: The patient has moderate nasopharyngeal bleeding in the setting of a supratherapeutic partial thromboplastin time (PTT). This may be due to the use of heparin, and there is a slight critical drop in hemoglobin levels.
2. Acute-on-chronic CHF: The patient was being diuresed on the floor but was unable to maintain his pressures. He also has pulmonary hypertension, which may be exacerbating his OSA. The patient's dilated heart and AF may be contributing to his worsening heart failure.
3. Atrial fibrillation/ventricular ectopy: The patient's AF is likely contributing to his worsening HF. Cardioversion is planned when the patient is stable, and the use of amiodarone is mentioned.
4. Leg ulcers: The patient has vascular disease and may require surgical debridement in the future.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)/pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), and severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD) presenting with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation (AF).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute-on-Chronic CHF: The patient has a history of CHF, and his current presentation suggests worsening of the condition due to fluid overload and renal dysfunction.
2. Atrial Fibrillation/Ventricular Ectopy: The patient is likely experiencing AF, which is contributing to his worsening heart failure. There is also evidence of ventricular ectopy.
3. Lower Extremity Ulcers: The patient has multiple ulcers on his lower extremities, which are likely related to his PVD. These ulcers may require debridement and management by a vascular specialist.
4. Acute-on-Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has worsened due to diuresis and poor forward flow. This condition needs close monitoring, and medication dosages may need to be adjusted based on renal function.
5. AMS (Altered Mental Status): The patient's AMS may be due to low blood pressure, infection-induced delirium, or OSA. Further evaluation

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)/pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and ulcerative colitis. He presents with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation (AF).

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)/pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and ulcerative colitis. He was admitted with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure.

The patient experienced a nasopharyngeal bleed, which was likely due to a supratherapeutic prothrombin time (PTT). Heparin was held, and the nasal cavity was packed with gauze. ENT consultation was called, and afrin nasal spray was given.

The patient's heart failure was managed with diuretics (Lasix and metolazone) to achieve an adequate output goal. Milrinone was considered to increase blood pressure if needed. Cardioversion was planned when the patient became more stable, and ACE inhibitor therapy was restarted once renal function improved. Beta-blocker therapy was held until heart failure was more stable.

Atrial fibrillation/ventricular ectopy was present, and cardioversion was considered to benefit the patient. The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) was subtherapeutic, so a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was planned.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), and severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD). He presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Overnight, he developed respiratory failure requiring intubation and hypotension requiring pressors. Possible etiologies for his hypotension include sepsis, poor forward flow due to heart failure, or blood clot in the lungs. He also has a large pleural effusion, multiple leg ulcers, and a history of ulcerative colitis, tophaceous gout, thrombocytopenia, hypothyroidism, and DMII.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to sepsis, poor forward flow in heart failure, or blood clot in the lungs. Further evaluation and treatment are needed, including the insertion of a Swan catheter to obtain more information on hemodynamics.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be related to his heart failure, complicated by poor forward flow from atrial fibrillation. Additionally, during intubation, a large clot was suctioned out, indicating the possibility of additional blood clot in the lungs. A bronchoscopy should be considered

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of afib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension requiring pressors.
   .
   # Hypotension: The patient developed hypotension overnight and is now
   on pressors. He also received aggressive fluid resuscitation overnight.
   There are several possible etiologies for the patient
s hypotension.
   First, he could be septic. He does have a leukocytosis; however, he
   does not have a fever or positive blood cultures at this point.
   - will add a second pressor (vasopressin)
   .
   # Bleeding: Pt noted to have moderate nasopharyngeal bleeding in the
   setting of a supratherapeutic PTT. Noted to have a slight crit drop
   this morning.
   - will pack nasal cavity with gauze
   - call ENT
   - Afrin nasal spray
   - holding heparin gtt
   - continue to trend Hct
   .
   # Acute on chronic CHF: Pt was being diuresed on the floor, but was
   unable to maintain his pressures. Pt had a dilated heart. Pt also has
   pulmonary HTN which may be [**1-7**] his OSA. The thought is that pt
s a/fib
   is contributing to his HF.
   - continue lasix gtt and metolazone to achieve I/O goal of -1to2 L for
   the day
   - may need milrinone to increase BP if not able to tolerate gtt
   - cardioversion when stable
   - will restart ACE once renal function improves
   - hold BB until HF more stable
   - continue ASA 81mg
   - norepi for BP support while on milrinone
   .
   # Atrial fib/ventricular ectopy: Likely contributing to his worsening
   HF. Pt does appear to tolearte being in afib. Likely will benifit from
   cardioversion. Pt was subtheraputic on his coumadin so will need TEE
   - holding heparin gtt in the setting of bleeding (see above)
   - cont amio
   - TEE when clinically stable
   .
   # LE ulcers: Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridement in future. WBC was elevated and temp was lower, so abx were
   broadened from Cipro to cefepime.
   - will continue vanco/cefepime/flagyl for now
   - f/u blood cx results
   - vascular recs regarding possible debridement
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: Cr/GFR was at baseline on admission,
   now worsened in setting of diuresis and poor forward flow. Prior to his
   admission in [**9-13**] baseline Cr was 1.7, range seems to have been
   1.5-2.0.  Creatinine is 2.5 this morning.
   - monitor with diuresis
   - renally dose meds
   - renal recs appreciated
   .
   .
   # OSA: pt refuses bipap, venous ABG shows CO2 renention. This may
   expain his sleepiness.
   - consider trying a nasal bipap, unsure if pt has tried this type
   .
   # L pleural effusion: Likely transudative in setting of CHF. Small and
   stable on cxr [**2-23**]
   - will monitor
   - if enlarges or pt is febrile, consider a dx tap
   .
   # Ulcerative Colitis: Pt without current sx. Pt is on 20mg prednisone
   qday (normally Q48 hrs at home).
   - continue steriods for now, while pt is having transient hypotension,
   once improved will change back to home dose
   .
   # Tophaceous Gout: Diffuse tophi on exam.
   - continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol
   - holding home colchicine for now
   - on increased steroid dose
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: chronic, s/p eval with negative HIT Ab, see last
   d/c summary.
   - will monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continuing home dose, TSH normal, total T4 low, but
   pt has been on amio (unsure if level was checked before or after it was
   started)
   - continue current dose
   - consider rechecking thyroid labs

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, renal failure, respiratory failure, and impaired skin integrity. The patient presented with symptoms of respiratory distress and hypercarbia, leading to endotracheal intubation. He also had an episode of epistaxis, for which a patch was placed on the nasal septum. The patient required increasing doses of norepinephrine to maintain blood pressure and experienced tachycardia. A unit of packed red blood cells was transfused to improve hemodynamics.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may lead to further deterioration in lung function, potentially requiring mechanical ventilation and increasing the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure can progress to chronic renal failure, leading to worsening kidney function and the need for renal replacement therapy such as dialysis.
3. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of heart failure and the use of vasoactive agents like norepinephrine may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.
4. Infection: Prolonged immobility and invasive lines increase the risk of hospital-acquired infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and cath

   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of a fib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension requiring pressors.
   # Hypotension: Currently on 0.08 norepinephrine + stable vasopressin
   with MAPS ranging 46-75. Has EF 25%,CVP increased from 6 y/d to 18
   today in the setting of transfusiong 3U today, with pt almost 7L
   positive LOS. Clinically edematous, all consistent with volume overload
   and poor forward flow as etiology. [**Month (only) 11**] be some contribution to
   hypotension from sedating medications. Also started on high dose
   steroids y/d given suspicion for suppressed adrenal axis in setting of
   chronic steroid use. Does have widened pulse pressure, low diastolics,
   less consistent with cardiogenic shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also be hypovolemic from
   blood loss. CXR could not exclude PNA, however had unremarkable bronch,
   but arguing against sepsis is that he has been afebrile, continues to
   have an elevated (but down trending WBC)and Blood, urine, stool,
   bronchial washings NGTD for infectious source/sepsis.
   -would consider swaning,better handle on hemodynamics. Difficulty of
   swan is that she has large IV, can reinitiate IV.
   -Defer HD for now, may be able to improve renal function by optimizing
   forward flow
   -wean off pressors if possible.
   -strict ins/outs
   -goal even to negative 500cc
   -? wean high dose steroids.
   -continue broad spectrum abx with vanc/cefepime/flagyll.
   .
   Rythm: EF on echo had worsened from 40-55% to 25% which was attibuted
   to his ectopy. He is now s/p cardioversion for a-flutter y/d with
   improved perfusion as indicated by improving BUN/CR. Pt continues to be
   in sinus rythm with some ectopy/tachycardia, with possible contribution
   from leovphed. Was on heparin bridge to coumadin however
   supratherapeutic PTT at low gtt infusion with spontaneous bleeding from
   broken skin, OP, dark, guaic positive stools, thus heparin held.
   Will continue to hold heparin given possible HD line placement later
   today. s/p HD line placement can restart heparin/bridge to coumadin
   with plan 4 weeks anticoagulation s/p cardioversion.

   -continue telemetry
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, severe peripheral vascular disease, and ulcerative colitis. The patient presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, requiring pressors for hypotension and vasopressin for fluid balance.

The patient's ejection fraction (EF) has worsened from 40-55% to 25%, indicating severely depressed biventricular systolic function. He also has mild mitral regurgitation, mild aortic stenosis, and complex atheroma in the descending aorta and aortic arch. These findings are consistent with his known history of heart failure and pulmonary hypertension.

The patient's respiratory status has been deteriorating, leading to respiratory failure. He has profound epistaxis, which necessitated semi-elective intubation for airway protection. His pulmonary vascular congestion, interstitial edema, and opacities on chest X-ray raise concerns for pulmonary edema and possible infection or aspiration. 

The patient's renal function has been improving with optimized hemodynamics and conversion to sinus rhythm. However, he still has none-gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary to renal failure. 

Coagulopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding are also concerns, given the patient's history

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of multiple comorbidities, including diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, renal failure (both acute and chronic), and impaired skin integrity. The patient presented with massive fluid overload, acute-on-chronic renal failure, and respiratory failure requiring intubation. He also had hypotension that was initially thought to be due to hypovolemia but is now believed to be cardiogenic or distributive shock. The patient has evidence of volume overload on chest X-ray and clinically, but there are also findings concerning for pneumonia. The patient has a yeast bacteremia, and his primary pulmonary process is ongoing. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started, including micafungin.

The patient also has a coagulopathy, with a history of ulcerative colitis and chronic prednisone therapy. He is currently receiving high-dose steroids, and his platelet count is low. Differential diagnoses include disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), and hemolysis. Hemolysis labs are negative, and HIT/ADAMTS13 is negative in the past. The patient has a history of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

The patient's acute-on-chronic renal failure has improved likely due to improved forward flow

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, renal failure, respiratory failure, epistaxis, impaired skin integrity, and chronic renal failure. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure and acute renal failure. 

24-hour events:
- Labs not suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
- Administered 5 mg IV vitamin K.
- Started IV pantoprazole and stopped aspirin.
- Decreased vancomycin dosing to every 48 hours.
- Consulted wound care for sacral wound.
- Hematocrit relatively stable.
- GI believes melanotic stools and blood in NG tube are likely related to recent epistaxis.
- Recommended trending Hct and transfusing PRN.
- Also felt that thrombocytopenia and platelet dysfunction in the setting of renal failure are likely contributors.
- Emergent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) if clinically unstable, EGD when stable otherwise.
- Renal recommending Swan-Ganz catheter.
- Recommended getting urine electrolytes and holding off on hemodialysis line at this time.
- Urine electrolytes showed urea nitrogen 573, creatinine 66, sodium <10, osmolality 397; suggest prerenal azotemia.
- Allergies: No known drug allergies.

   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of a fib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension requiring pressors.
   # Hypotension: Currently on 0.08 norepinephrine + stable vasopressin
   with MAPS ranging 46-75. Has EF 25%,CVP increased from 6 y/d to 18
   today in the setting of transfusiong 3U today, with pt almost 7L
   positive LOS. Clinically edematous, all consistent with volume overload
   and poor forward flow as etiology. [**Month (only) 11**] be some contribution to
   hypotension from sedating medications. Also started on high dose
   steroids y/d given suspicion for suppressed adrenal axis in setting of
   chronic steroid use. Does have widened pulse pressure, low diastolics,
   less consistent with cardiogenic shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also be hypovolemic from
   blood loss. CXR could not exclude PNA, however had unremarkable bronch,
   but arguing against sepsis is that he has been afebrile, continues to
   have an elevated (but down trending WBC)and Blood, urine, stool,
   bronchial washings NGTD for infectious source/sepsis.
   -would consider swaning,better handle on hemodynamics. Difficulty of
   swan is that she has large IV, can reinitiate IV.
   -Defer HD for now, may be able to improve renal function by optimizing
   forward flow
   -wean off pressors if possible.
   -strict ins/outs
   -goal even to negative 500cc
   -? wean high dose steroids.
   -continue broad spectrum abx with vanc/cefepime/flagyll.
   .
   Rythm: EF on echo had worsened from 40-55% to 25% which was attibuted
   to his ectopy. He is now s/p cardioversion for a-flutter y/d with
   improved perfusion as indicated by improving BUN/CR. Pt continues to be
   in sinus rythm with some ectopy/tachycardia, with possible contribution
   from leovphed. Was on heparin bridge to coumadin however
   supratherapeutic PTT at low gtt infusion with spontaneous bleeding from
   broken skin, OP, dark, guaic positive stools, thus heparin held.
   Will continue to hold heparin given possible HD line placement later
   today. s/p HD line placement can restart heparin/bridge to coumadin
   with plan 4 weeks anticoagulation s/p cardioversion.
   [**Name (NI) **] PTT/INR (currently 41.7 /2.2)
   Wean pressors as tolerated
   Continue amnio 400 [**Hospital1 **]
   -Resume ACE once renal function improves, BB once off pressors, BP
   tolerates.
   -continue telemetry
   .
   Coagulopathy/GI bleed: hx Ulcerative colitis, on chronic prednisone
   therapy, currently getting high dose steroids. Last colonoscopy [**2173**],
   no flares in years. Black stools, unstable HCT despite transfusion. Now
   with platelets at 45 this am from [**Age over 90 **] y/d. DD includes DIC, HIT,
   hemolysis. Hemolysis labs negative.
   f/u DIC labs, f/u peripheral smear, consider sending HIT labs (has been
   thrombocytopenic in past this hospitalization)
   -GI consulted ? scope.
   FFP x 2 unit, vitamin K 5, consider platelets. recheck CBC. if needed,
   additional RBC transfusion
   TID crits
   .
   Respiratory Distress: semi elective intubation for airway protection in
   setting of profound epistaxis. Also has persistent pulmonary vascular
   congestion, interstitial edema consistent with heart failure and hx
   pulmonary HTN and opacities that were equivocal for
   atelectasis vs infection vs aspiration. Barriers to extubation:
   sedation (fentanyl, versed), requires further procedurization easier
   performed while intubated.
   .
   Acute on chronic renal failure:
   Renal failure improved likely [**1-7**] to improved forward flow with
   conversion to sinus.Does have none gap metabolic acidosis likely
   secondary to renal failure, unable to make adequate ammonia to excrete
   acid. [**Month (only) 11**] consider bicarb in future if continues to [**Month (only) 1174**] down.
   -continue to optimize hemodynamics, consider swan.
   -[**Month (only) 1174**] lytes [**Hospital1 **]
   -defer HD line for now
   -appreciate renal recs.
   .
   # LE ulcers: Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridement in future. WBC was elevated and temp was lower, so abx were
   broadened from Cipro to cefepime.
   - will continue vanco/cefepime/flagyl for now
   - f/u blood cx results
   - vascular recs regarding possible debridement
   .
   # OSA:
   - intubated at this time
   # Tophaceous Gout: Diffuse tophi on exam.
   - continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol
   - holding home colchicine for now
   - stress dose steroids as above
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: chronic, s/p eval with negative HIT Ab, see last
   d/c summary.
   - will monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continuing home dose, TSH normal, total T4 low, but
   pt has been on amio (unsure if level was checked before or after it was
   started)
    continue current dose
   - consider rechecking thyroid labs
   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with multiple comorbidities, including diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure (diastolic), atrial fibrillation, impaired skin integrity, and chronic kidney disease. He presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrosis. Currently, he is in respiratory failure after intubation, requiring pressors for hypotension, and has a suspected pulmonary embolism. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient is currently on a combination of norepinephrine and vasopressin to maintain blood pressure, indicating ongoing hypotension. The MAP ranges from 46-75, which is below the normal range of 75-90 mmHg.
2. Coagulopathy/GI bleed: The patient has black stools, unstable hematocrit despite transfusion, and thrombocytopenia. There is a concern for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), or hemolysis. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
3. Respiratory Distress: The patient is semi-elective intubated for airway protection due to profound epistaxis. He also has persistent pulmonary vascular congestion, interstitial edema consistent with heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension. These factors increase the risk

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic renal failure, peripheral vascular disease, and topheaceous gout. He presented with massive fluid overload, acute-on-chronic renal failure, respiratory failure, and hypotension requiring pressors. The patient underwent synchronized cardioversion for atrial flutter with improved perfusion. He has been on high-dose steroids due to suspected suppressed adrenal axis. The patient has black stools, unstable hematocrit, and thrombocytopenia. His rhythm has improved, but his renal function remains poor. He has diffuse tophi on exam and a history of thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Coagulopathy/GI bleed: The patient has black stools, unstable hematocrit, and thrombocytopenia. These findings suggest a possible gastrointestinal bleed. Further evaluation with GI consultation and stool analysis is needed. FFP, vitamin K, and platelet transfusion may be considered if necessary.
2. Respiratory distress: The patient has profound epistaxis and persistent pulmonary vascular congestion. Intubation was performed for airway protection and to improve oxygenation. Weaning off pressors and extubation will depend on the patient's clinical stability.
3. Acute-on-chronic renal failure: The patient

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure (diastolic), atrial fibrillation, renal failure (acute on chronic), respiratory failure (acute), epistaxis, impaired skin integrity, chronic kidney disease, and peripheral vascular disease. He presents with massive fluid overload, acute-on-chronic renal failure, and respiratory failure requiring intubation. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing hypotension, which could be due to hypovolemia or cardiogenic/distributive shock. Volume overload on CXR and clinical findings suggest the possibility of cardiogenic shock.

2. Coagulopathy: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis and is on chronic prednisone therapy. He is currently receiving high-dose steroids, and his platelet count is low. Differential diagnosis includes disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), and hemolysis. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.

3. Yeast Bacteremia: The patient has evidence of yeast bacteremia, which requires broadening antibiotics to include micafungin. The primary pulmonary process is ongoing, and he is not a candidate for extubation at present.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes type II, severe peripheral vascular disease, and multiple ulcerations. He presents with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrosis. The patient is now in respiratory failure following intubation and requires pressor support for hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure (diastolic), atrial fibrillation, renal failure (acute on chronic), respiratory failure (acute), epistaxis, impaired skin integrity, and chronic kidney disease. The patient presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrosis. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient's condition is complicated by hypotension requiring pressors, yeast bacteremia likely from a central line infection, coagulopathy, and LE ulcers. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, chronic renal failure, and impaired skin integrity.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory status and appropriate antibiotic therapy should be maintained.
2. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient has yeast bacteremia likely originating from a central line infection. Proper care and maintenance of central lines, along with appropriate antibiotic therapy, should be continued to prevent further complications.

   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension requiring pressors.

   cardioversion to sinus rhythm. Likely primarily cardiogenic in nature.
   Currently on low-dose norepi. Yesterday, pressor was weaned off;
   however, after, pt
s UOP was noted to trend down and pressor was
   restarted.
   -continue vanc/cefepime/flagyl, plus micafungin
   -attempt to wean pressors
   -goal CVP in upper teens to low 20
s, as that is when pt seems to have
   better UOP
   -consider giving colloid with Lasix to improve diuresis
   .
   # Volume Overload: Likely related to poor forward flow in the setting
   of pt
s heart failure. As above, pt had improved UOP yesterday in the
   setting of a slightly higher CVP, after receiving blood and albumin.
   However, pressors were weaned down and UOP dropped off. Now, pt back on
   norepi.
   - consider giving blood/albumin, followed by Lasix to see if this will
   improve UOP
   - can also consider inotrope this evening if urine output does not
   improve
   - possible trial of CVVH tomorrow, will d/w renal
   .
   # Yeast bacteremia: Noted on positive blood culture. Most likely source
   is central line (now resited).
   -continue micafungin

   ,

   -trend CBC, INR, PTT
   -holding off on further anticoagulation, consider pt
s recent bleeding
   problems on heparin gtt
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Renal failure likely prerenal. Cr

Summary:
Summary of the progress note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension (OSA/PHTN), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), and severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD) presenting with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrosis. The patient is currently intubated and in respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation. He has hypotension requiring vasopressors, metabolic acidosis, hypoxemia, and infection. 

Potential medical complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial, including hypovolemia, distributive (yeast in blood), and cardiogenic causes (CHF, ectopy). It has improved with resolution of bleeding and cardioversion to sinus rhythm, but he remains on low-dose norepinephrine plus vasopressin.
2. Yeast bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture indicating yeast bacteremia, most likely from a central line. The goal CVP is 20-24, and he should continue on micafungin, follow ID recommendations, and evaluate micro data.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation profile has improved, with an INR now at 1.8. Trend CBC, INR, and PTT.
4. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely prerenal and has improved with better forward flow. Follow renal recommendations, trend electrolytes, and consult nephrology.
5. Lower extremity ulcers: The patient has vascular involvement with leg ulcers. Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical debridement in the future. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics, follow blood culture results, consult podiatry, and consider no debridement needed at this time.
6. Tophaceous gout: The patient has diffuse tophi on exam. Continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol, holding home colchicine for now.
7. Ulcerative colitis: The patient is on chronic steroids. Stress dose steroids in setting of critical illness.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient is continuing home dose of levothyroxine, TSH normal, total T4 low. Continue current dose, unsure if level was checked before or after starting amiodarone.

Overall, the patient is in a critical condition with multiple medical complications requiring close monitoring and management.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, and severe peripheral vascular disease presenting with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of a fibrotic process. The patient is now in respiratory failure post intubation and has hypotension requiring pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Volume Overload: The patient has massive fluid overload likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure. Continued diuresis with Lasix is attempted, and if diuresis fails, albumin or blood transfusion may be considered.
2. Hypotension: Multiple etiologies for hypotension including hypovolemia (bleeding, diuresis), distributive (yeast in blood), and cardiogenic (CHF, frequent ectopy) are present. The patient is currently on low-dose norepinephrine. Pressor weaning was attempted but had to be restarted due to decreasing urine output.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient has inspiratory effort that is poor, unexplained by lung compliance or resistance. Sedation and low bicarbonate levels with reduced respiratory drive may be contributing factors. Further trials of weaned pressure and diuresis are needed.
4. Yeast Bacteremia: A positive blood culture indicates yeast bacteremia, most likely originating

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted for ulcer debridement. He has a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure (diastolic), atrial fibrillation, renal failure (acute), respiratory failure (acute), epistaxis, and impaired skin integrity. The patient is currently in the ICU due to pneumonia and heart failure. He has been experiencing hyperglycemia and has been started on insulin gtt. The patient received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells and attempted diuresis with Lasix and Diuril. If diuresis does not work, CVVH is unlikely to succeed, and inotropic-assisted diuresis could be considered. The patient's tube feeds have been stopped for the night. Allergies include no known drug allergies. The patient has been on various antibiotics, including vancomycin, micafungin, cefipime, and metronidazole. Infusions include midazolam, fentanyl, furosemide, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium. The patient's vitals are stable, with a heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 110/61 to 139/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation at 100%, and sinus rhythm. The patient's weight is 127.9 kg, height is 73 inches, and CVP is 15 mmHg. Fluid balance shows a total input of 1,965 mL and total output of 990 mL. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and RSBI of 27. ABG results indicate a pH of 7.44, PaCO2 of 32 mmHg, HCO3 of 18 mEq/L, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 433. Physical examination findings include peripheral vascular assessment not assessed, skin not assessed, and neurologic assessment not assessed. Laboratory results show leukocyte count of 8.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.3 g/dL, glucose of 226 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, sodium of 128 mg/dL, potassium of 3.8 mEq/L, and chloride of 102 mEq/L. Imaging shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, congestive heart failure, and areas of opacity in the right upper and both lower lobes, suggesting pneumonia. The patient has been diagnosed with bacteremia, diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure (diastolic), atrial fibrillation, renal failure (acute), respiratory failure (acute),

Summary:
The patient's chief complaint is an ulcer debridement, but they were admitted to the ICU for heart failure and atrial fibrillation. The patient has a history of systolic congestive heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, severe peripheral vascular disease, and multiple ulcerations. They presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrosis. Now, the patient is in respiratory failure after intubation and has hypotension requiring pressors.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9Â°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 110/61 mmHg to 139/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination shows that they are intubated, opening their eyes and nodding to verbal stimuli. They have faint hair scattered on the chest, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops appreciated, clear lungs anteriorly, soft non-tender abdomen, and pitting edema in all four extremities. There is also a large ecchymosis present on the right arm.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 8.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.3 g/dL, glucose of 226 mg/dL, sodium of 141 mEq/L, potassium of 3.8 mEq/L, chloride of 102 mEq/L, total bilirubin of 0.9 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, calcium of 8.3 mg/dL, magnesium of 2.6 mg/dL, and phosphate of 3.5 mg/dL. The patient's blood cultures are positive for yeast.

The patient's imaging shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with persistent congestive heart failure. There are more confluent areas of opacity in the right upper and both lower lobes, representing pneumonia that appears slightly worse in the right upper lobe and slightly better in the left lower lobe. There is also a moderate right and small left pleural effusion.

The patient's assessment and plan include multiple medical complications such as volume overload, hypotension, respiratory failure, yeast bacteremia, coagulopathy, acute-on-chronic renal failure, leg ulcers, tophaceous gout, ulcerative colitis, and hypothyroidism. The patient is on various medications including vancomycin, cefepime, metronidazole, pantoprazole, heparin, furosemide, midazolam, fentanyl, and insulin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening heart failure, worsening renal function, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and further episodes of hypotension.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of a fib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension requiring pressors.
   # Volume Overload
   Likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of pt
s heart
   failure. As above, pt had improved UOP yesterday in the setting of a
   slightly higher CVP, after receiving blood and albumin. However,
   pressors were weaned down and UOP dropped off. Norepi  off now.
   - Attempt continued diuresis with Lasix given some progress since
   midnight.
   - Failing diuretic goals, give albumin or blood
   - Failing those products, consider restarting pressors
   - possible trial of CVVH tomorrow, will d/w renal
   Remains intubated.  A combination of furosemide and hydrodiuril had
   resulted in 30 cc/hr urine output.
   Renal is not enthusiastic about CVVH in the absence of success with
   diuresis with diuretics.
   Tricuspid regurgitation may remain an impediment to diuresis.
   Continue antibiotics and antimicrobial
   Consider ionotropic support with IV lasix to improve diuresis.
   # Hypotension: Multiple possible etiologies, including hypovolemia
   (bleeding, diuresis), distributive (given yeast in blood), cardiogenic
   (given CHF, frequent ectopy). Improved with resolution of bleeding and
   cardioversion to sinus rhythm. Likely primarily cardiogenic in nature.
   Currently on low-dose norepi. Yesterday, pressor was weaned off;
   however, after, pt
s UOP was noted to trend down and pressor was
   restarted.
   - Septic
 appreciate ID input
   - continue vanc/cefepime/flagyl, plus micafungin (likely to fluconazole
   today)
   - goal CVP in upper teens to low 20
s, as that is when pt seems to have
   better UOP, but  this will need to be balanced with overload/diuresis
   (likely can increase CVP as well as facilitate diuresis and treat
   anasarca with albumin/blood)
 see above.
   # Respiratory Faliure
   Per CXR, likely large component of edema given CXR findings after
   reducing pressure support. Inspiratory effort is also poor at present,
   which is unexplained. Obesity and sedation likely contributors. Lung
   compliance in 40s and resistance acceptable. Therefore neuromuscular.
   [**Month (only) 11**] be due to sedation and low bicarb with reduced drive. Needs longer
   trials of weaned pressure and further diuresis.
   # Yeast bacteremia
   Noted on positive blood culture. Most likely source is central line
   (now resited).
   -continue micafungin (converting to fluconazole)
   -D/w ID, chance of fungal pneumonia
   -f/u ID recs
   -f/u micro data
   -consult ophtho to evaluate for [**Female First Name (un) **] endophthalmitis
   # Coagulopathy: Improved, with INR now 1.2.
   -trend CBC, INR, PTT
   -holding off on further anticoagulation, consider pt
s recent bleeding
   problems on heparin gtt
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Renal failure likely prerenal. Cr
   slightly improved overnight in the setting of increased UOP.
   -f/u renal recs
   -trend lytes [**Hospital1 **]
   -consider CVVH tomorrow, as above
   # LE ulcers: Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridement in future. On broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - continue vanco/cefepime/flagyl
   - f/u blood cx results
   - per vascular no debridement needed.
   # Tophaceous Gout: Diffuse tophi on exam.
   - continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol
   - holding home colchicine for now
   # Ulcerative colitis: On chronic steroids.
   - stress dose steroids in setting of critical illness
   - Halve dose of steroids today
   # Hypothyroidism: continuing home dose of levothyoxine, TSH normal,
   total T4 low, but pt has been on amio (unsure if level was checked
   before or after it was started)
   - continue current dose

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)/pulmonary hypertension (PHTN), chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), and severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD) presenting with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrosis. The patient is now in respiratory failure post intubation and has hypotension requiring pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Volume Overload: The patient's massive fluid overload needs to be managed through diuresis, blood transfusions, or albumin administration. If diuretic goals are not achieved, restarting pressors may be necessary.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to various causes, including hypovolemia, distributive, or cardiogenic factors. Pressors have been used to maintain blood pressure, but the patient's urine output dropped after weaning off the pressors.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to several factors, including obesity, sedation, reduced lung compliance, and neuromuscular weakness. Trials of weaned pressure and further diuresis are recommended.
4. Yeast Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast bacteremia, likely originating from the central line. Antibiotic treatment should continue with micafung

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is experiencing several medical complications. These include:

1. Heart failure (HF) and atrial fibrillation (AFIB): The patient has a history of heart failure and is currently presenting with acute decompensated heart failure. The presence of AFIB is also noted in the medical history.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The ventilator settings indicate that they are receiving supplemental oxygen and have a set respiratory rate.

3. Renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic renal failure and is currently experiencing acute renal failure. This is evident from the laboratory results showing elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output.

4. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): Although not explicitly mentioned in the progress note, the elevated blood glucose levels suggest poorly controlled diabetes, which may lead to DKA.

5. Ulcerative colitis: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease that causes inflammation and ulcers in the colon and rectum.

6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin integrity is compromised, as indicated by the presence of a pressure ulcer.

7. Altered mental status: The patient exhibits altered mental status, which may be due to various factors such as medication effects, electrolyte imbalances, or sepsis.

8. Bacteremia: The patient has bacteremia, as evidenced by the positive blood cultures.

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Volume Overload: The patient has signs of fluid overload with high CVP, low urine output, and worsening respiratory failure. This can be due to heart failure and the administration of blood products.

2. Hypotension: The patient experienced hypotension, which could be caused by various factors such as hypovolemia, distributive shock, or cardiogenic shock. This may require continuous monitoring and treatment with pressors.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, possibly due to fluid accumulation in the lungs. Positive pressure ventilation may be required to manage this condition.

4. Yeast Fungemia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast, indicating a possible fungal infection. This needs to be treated with antifungal medications like fluconazole.

5. Coagulopathy: The patient had a coagulopathy indicated by an elevated INR. This may be related to malnutrition or other factors. Monitoring of coagulation parameters is necessary, and further anticoagulation may be avoided due to recent bleeding problems.

6. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a need for close monitoring of renal parameters. Consideration should be given to renal replacement therapy, such as continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH).

7. Lower Extremity Ulcers

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, severe peripheral vascular disease, and atrial fibrillation.
- The patient presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation. He is currently in respiratory failure following intubation and has hypotension that was previously managed with pressors.
- The patient's nutrition is being provided through a NovaSource Renal (Full) at 25 mL/hour.
- Blood cultures have shown the presence of yeast, indicating a possible yeast fungemia. The central line is suspected as the source of infection.
- The patient's coagulopathy has improved, with an INR now at 1.4. Further monitoring of CBC, INR, and PTT is recommended.
- The patient has acute-on-chronic renal failure, likely prerenal in nature. Renal function is being closely monitored, and consideration is being given to continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH).
- The patient has lower extremity ulcers, which are being managed by a vascular specialist. Tissue culture results indicate a polymicrobial chronic infection.
- The patient also has tophi related to tophaceous gout. Renal dosing of allopurinol is being continued.

   Assessment:
   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of a fib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension off pressors.
   Plan:
   # Volume Overload
   Likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of pt
s heart
   failure. As above, pt had improved UOP in the setting of a slightly
   higher CVP, after receiving blood and albumin. Restarted milrinone
   along with IV lasix, no significant improvement in output, still net
   positive.
   - Will discuss with renal possible trial of CVVH
   - Transfuse of 1 unit PRBCs to help maintain CVP in low 20s
   # Hypotension: Resolved. Multiple possible etiologies, including
   hypovolemia (bleeding, diuresis), distributive (given yeast in blood),
   cardiogenic (given CHF, frequent ectopy). Improved with resolution of
   bleeding and cardioversion to sinus rhythm. Likely primarily
   cardiogenic in nature.
   - Transfuse per above
   - CVVH per above as ultrafiltration will assist in Frank-Starling
   physiology
   - continue vanc/cefepime/flagyl, plus increased fluconazole from 200 mg
   IV Q24H to 400 mg IV Q24H (per ID and pharm)
   - goal CVP in upper teens to low 20
s, as that is when pt seems to have
   better UOP
   - Guiac all stools
   # Respiratory Faliure
   Per CXR, likely large component of edema given CXR findings after
   reducing pressure support. This suggests pt is dependent on positive
   pressure to keep fluid out of lungs. Inspiratory effort is also poor at
   present, which is unexplained. Obesity and sedation likely
   contributors. Lung compliance in 40s and resistance acceptable.
   Therefore neuromuscular. [**Month (only) 11**] be due to sedation and low bicarb with
   reduced drive. Needs longer trials of weaned pressure and further
   diuresis.
   - continue daily weaning trials
   # Yeast fungemia
   Noted on positive blood culture. Most likely source was central line
   (now resited).  No [**Female First Name (un) 444**] endophthalmitis per optho
   -continue fluconazole
   -f/u ID recs
   -f/u micro data
   # Coagulopathy: Improved, with INR now 1.4. Possibly nutrition related.
   -trend CBC, INR, PTT
   -holding off on further anticoagulation, consider pt
s recent bleeding
   problems on heparin gtt
   -if no adequate HCT bump consider small dose of vitamin K
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Renal failure likely prerenal. Cr
   stable at 2.0 (baseline 1.6-1.8)
   -f/u renal recs
   -trend lytes [**Hospital1 **]
   -consider CVVH tomorrow, as above
   # LE ulcers: Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridement in future. On broad spectrum antibiotics. Tissue culture
   results yield GPCs in pairs/clusters and GNRs suggesting polymicrobial
   chronic infection.
   - Await speciation/sensitivities
   - ID recs
   - continue vanco/cefepime/flagyl
   - f/u blood cx results
   - f/u vascular recs (Do they think this is Osteo or no active signs of
   osteo?)
   # Tophaceous Gout: Diffuse tophi on exam.
   - continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol
   - holding home colchicine for now
   # Ulcerative colitis: On chronic steroids.
   - stress dose steroids in setting of critical illness (halved

   # Hypothyroidism: continuing home dose of levothyoxine, TSH normal,

   - continue current dose

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, severe peripheral vascular disease, and atrial fibrillation. He presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation. The patient is now in respiratory failure post-intubation and has hypotension off pressors.

The patient's current medications include furosemide (Lasix), milrinone, heparin sodium (prophylaxis), fentanyl, and other ICU medications. 

His physical examination reveals that he is intubated and sedated, with obesity and anasarca. He opens his eyes and nods to verbal stimuli appropriately. His heart sounds are faint and no murmurs or gallops are appreciated. His lungs are clear anteriorly, but he has pitting edema in all four extremities and large ecchymosis on his right arm.

The patient's lab results show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), glucose, and potassium. His white blood cell count is slightly elevated. The urine microalbumin-to-creatinine ratio is 24.0%. His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis indicates respiratory acidosis.

The patient's imaging shows slightly improved right lung opacities, consistent with pneumonia. Bilateral effusions and a waxing-and-waning pattern suggest

The patient is currently in respiratory failure post-intubation and has hypotension off pressors.

The patient's medical history includes multiple ulcerations, CHF, OSA/PHTN, CKD, DMII, and severe PVD. The patient's family history is not mentioned.

Summary:
The patient is a 73-year-old male who presented with an ulcer debridement. The patient was admitted to the hospital and later transferred to the ICU due to heart failure and atrial fibrillation. The patient's medical history includes diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, chronic renal failure, respiratory failure, epistaxis, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted below.

The patient's current vital signs are as follows: temperature of 37.4 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 92 beats per minute, blood pressure of 127/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate set at 24 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.41, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 250, and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 31.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated levels of white blood cell count (WBC), hemoglobin (Hb), and platelets (Plt). The patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and serum creatinine (Cr) levels are within normal range. The patient's electrolyte levels are also within normal limits. The patient's imaging shows confirmation of dialysis line placement.

The patient's microbiology results indicate the presence of gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters, along with gram-negative rods. Further identification and sensitivity testing on all organisms is requested.

The patient's current medications include calcium gluconate, potassium chloride, and other ICU medications. The patient's nutrition is being provided through NovaSource Renal (Full) at a rate of 35 mL/hour. The patient's glycemic control is being managed with regular insulin sliding scale.

The patient's assessment and plan include alterations in nutrition, bacteremia, diabetes mellitus type II, hypothyroidism, ulcerative colitis, heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AFIB), renal failure, acute respiratory failure, epistaxis, impaired skin integrity, altered mental status, and chronic renal failure. The patient's ICU care involves monitoring of vital signs, arterial line, multi-lumen line, and dialysis catheter. Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers is also being provided. The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is pending.

   66 yo male with hx of CHF, DMII, CRF stage III, HTN, chronic AFIB, and
   [**Hospital 1635**] transfered from [**Hospital3 1672**] on [**2177-2-19**] due to extensive  lower
   extremity ulcers. He was initailly on the vascular service then
   transfered to the medicine service on [**2177-2-20**] due to needed more tx for
   [**Last Name (un) **] HF and acute on chronic renal failure and concern of his rhythm.
   24 Hour Events:

   Assessment:
   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of a fib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension off pressors.
   Plan:
   # Volume Overload
   Likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of pt
s heart
   failure. As above, pt had improved UOP in the setting of a slightly
   higher CVP, after receiving blood and albumin. Restarted milrinone
   along with IV lasix, no significant improvement in output, still net
   positive.  Pt is 3.7 L negative in 24 hrs. ABx redosed for CVVH.
   - Emphasize SLOW ultrafiltration to allow adequate kidney perfusion
   - continue  CVVH goal 100-150 per hr
   # Hypotension: Improved. Multiple possible etiologies, including
   hypovolemia (bleeding, diuresis), distributive (given yeast in blood),
   cardiogenic (given CHF, frequent ectopy). Improved with resolution of
   bleeding and cardioversion to sinus rhythm. Likely primarily
   cardiogenic in nature.
   - CVVH per above as ultrafiltration will assist in Frank-Starling
   physiology
   - continue vanc/cefepime, plus increased fluconazole 400 mg IV Q24H
   (per ID and pharm)
   - stop flagyl per ID, start bactrim at cvvh dose (find out today)
   - goal CVP in upper teens to low 20
s, as that is when pt seems to have
   better UOP
   # Respiratory Failure and Vent.
   Will wean today
 fighting AC and satble on PSV 8/5 overnight. Gases
   good. Per CXR, likely large component of edema given CXR findings after
   reducing pressure support. This suggests pt is dependent on positive
   pressure to keep fluid out of lungs. Inspiratory effort is also poor at
   present, which is unexplained. Obesity and sedation likely
   contributors. Lung compliance in 40s and resistance acceptable.
   Therefore neuromuscular. [**Month (only) 11**] be due to sedation and low bicarb with
   reduced drive. Needs longer trials of weaned pressure and further
   diuresis.
   - will attempt extubation today
   - Convert to non-invasive mask
   # Yeast fungemia
   Noted on positive blood culture. Most likely source was central line
   (now resited).  No [**Female First Name (un) 444**] endophthalmitis per optho
   -continue fluconazole
   - contact ID re stenotrophamonas
   -f/u ID recs
   -f/u micro data
   - ? add bactrim
   # Low grade temp: In setting of CVVH.
   - Check C diff
   # Thrombocytopenia: possibly secondary to PPI.
   - Stop PPI once extubated
   # Coagulopathy: Improved, with INR now 1.4. Possibly nutrition related.
   -trend CBC, INR, PTT
   -holding off on further anticoagulation, consider pt
s recent bleeding
   problems on heparin gtt
   -if no adequate HCT bump consider small dose of vitamin K
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Renal failure likely prerenal. Cr
   stable at 2.0 (baseline 1.6-1.8)
   -f/u renal recs
   -trend lytes [**Hospital1 **]
   -consider CVVH tomorrow, as above
   # LE ulcers: Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridement in future. On broad spectrum antibiotics. Tissue culture
   results yield GPCs in pairs/clusters and GNRs suggesting polymicrobial
   chronic infection.
   - Await speciation/sensitivities
   - ID recs
   - continue vanco/cefepime
   - stop flagyl per ID
   - start bactrim with adjustment for cvvh
   - f/u blood cx results
   - f/u vascular recs (Do they think this is Osteo or no active signs of
   osteo?)
   # Tophaceous Gout: Diffuse tophi on exam.
   - continue renally adjusted dose of allopurinol
   - holding home colchicine for now
   - on steroids
   # Ulcerative colitis: On chronic steroids.
   - stress dose steroids in setting of critical illness (halved

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus type II, chronic renal failure stage III, hypertension, chronic atrial fibrillation, and chronic peripheral vascular disease. He was admitted due to extensive lower extremity ulcers and was initially on the vascular service before being transferred to the medicine service.

The patient presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of fibrotic cardiomyopathy. He is now in respiratory failure post intubation and has hypotension off pressors.

Plan:
- Slow ultrafiltration to allow adequate kidney perfusion
- Continue CVVH goal 100-150 per hour
- Improve forward flow in the setting of poor heart function
- Restart milrinone along with IV lasix
- Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and fluconazole
- Stop flagyl and start bactrim at CVVH dose
- Goal CVP in upper teens to low 20s to better understand the patient's response

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Volume Overload: The patient has a history of congestive heart failure and is presenting with massive fluid overload. This can lead to further deterioration of cardiac function and worsening of renal failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (

Summary:
Summary:
- 66-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus type II, chronic kidney disease stage III, hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation.
- Admitted to the ICU for ulcer debridement, but quickly became unstable with hypotension and respiratory failure.
- The patient has multiple comorbidities and is experiencing acute on chronic renal failure.
- He has a positive blood culture for yeast, suggesting a possible central line infection.
- The patient's thrombocytopenia may be secondary to PPI use.
- There are plans to attempt extubation today and convert to non-invasive mask ventilation.
- The patient has a history of chronic steroid use for ulcerative colitis and is currently on stress dose steroids.
- He also has a history of hypothyroidism, which is being managed with levothyroxine.
- The patient has diffuse tophi and a history of tophaceous gout, and allopurinol is being continued.
- His recent laboratory results show elevated potassium levels.
- The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to the presence of polymicrobial chronic infection in the lower extremity ulcers.

Potential medical complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive and required pressors for hemodynamic stability. This could be due to cardiogenic shock from heart failure, hypovolemia from diuresis or bleeding, or distributive shock from seps

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus type II, chronic renal failure stage III, hypertension, chronic atrial fibrillation, and extensive lower extremity ulcers. He was admitted due to extensive ulcers and was initially on the vascular service before being transferred to the medicine service. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, respiratory failure, and yeast fungemia. His renal function is compromised, and he has thrombocytopenia, coagulopathy, and anemia. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of multiple organ systems.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Volume Overload: The patient has massive fluid overload, likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure. Aggressive diuresis with IV lasix and CVVH are planned to manage this condition.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, distributive (yeast in blood), or cardiogenic causes. Transfusion and CVVH will help in managing hypotension.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is dependent on positive pressure to keep fluid out of the lungs. Daily weaning trials and further diuresis are planned to manage respiratory failure.
4. Yeast Fungemia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast, likely originating from a central line. Fluconazole will be continued, and the

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus type II (DMII), chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage III, hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the hospital due to extensive lower extremity ulcers and was initially on the vascular service before being transferred to the medicine service for further treatment of heart failure, acute on chronic renal failure, and rhythm concerns.

The patient's current condition is critical, with multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, volume overload, hypotension, yeast fungemia, coagulopathy, acute on chronic renal failure, and lower extremity ulcers. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with positive pressure support.

Plan:
The plan includes addressing each of the patient's medical complications. For volume overload, slow ultrafiltration is recommended to allow for adequate kidney perfusion, along with continuing CVVH at a goal rate of 100-200 per hour. Hypotension has resolved but may be primarily cardiogenic in nature, so transfusion and CVVH are recommended. The patient's respiratory failure requires continued weaning trials and further diuresis. Yeast fungemia is being treated with fluconazole, and the central line is being resited. Coagulopathy is improving but should be monitored with CBC, INR, and PTT. Acute on chronic renal failure is likely prerenal,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus type II, chronic renal failure stage III, hypertension, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU due to extensive lower extremity ulcers and later transferred to the CCU for heart failure and atrial fibrillation. The patient has been on various medications including vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl for suspected osteomyelitis, fluconazole for yeast infection, and is also receiving CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis). 

24-hour events:
- Vancomycin level was held due to a high level of 27.7.
- Allopurinol was stopped due to a concern of gout flare.
- Stress-dose steroids were reduced from 50 mg to 25 mg Hydrocortisone sodium succinate IV q24h.
- ID recommendations include continuing fluconazole, obtaining wound tissue culture results, and following up with micro data.
- Pharmacy recommendations for dose adjustment with CVVH include reducing fluconazole to 200 mg q24h and adjusting other medications as needed.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Volume Overload: The patient's massive fluid overload is likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure. The plan is to continue CVVH at a goal of 100-200 per hour, restart milrinone along with IV lasix, and aim for a CVP in the upper teens to low 20s.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has resolved, but multiple possible etiologies including hypovolemia, distributive, and cardiogenic causes were identified. The plan includes transfusing packed red blood cells, continuing CVVH, and adjusting medications accordingly.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a large component of edema as per CXR findings after reducing pressure support. The plan is to continue daily weaning trials, stop fentanyl gtt, and further diuresis.

4. Yeast Fungemia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast, most likely from a central line. The plan is to continue fluconazole, follow up with ID recommendations, and micro data.

5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy has improved, and the INR is now 1.4. The plan is to trend CBC, INR, and PTT, hold off on further anticoagulation, consider small dose of vitamin K if necessary, and avoid further bleeding.

6. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal failure is likely prerenal. The plan is to trend lytes, consider CVVH tomorrow, and follow up with renal recommendations.

7. Lower Extremity Ulcers: The patient's lower extremity ulcers are being managed by the

   Assessment:
   66 yo M with systolic CHF, OSA/Pulm HTN, CKD, DMII, severe PVD c/b
   multiple ulcerations presenting with massive fluid overload and acute
   on chronic renal failure in setting of a fib.  Now, in respiratory
   failure s/p intubation and with hypotension off pressors.
   Plan:
   # Volume Overload
   Likely related to poor forward flow in the setting of pt
s heart
   failure. Ultrafiltration has been somewhat too brisk than necessary as
   we also want to maintain perfusion to kidneys that we hope may regain
   some function. Pt is 2.8 L negative in 24 hrs. LOS pt still nearly 5L
   positive.
   - Continue ultrafiltration at current rates to allow adequate kidney
   perfusion per renal
   - continue CVVH goal 75-100 per hr
   # Hypotension: Improved. Multiple possible etiologies, including
   hypovolemia (bleeding, diuresis), distributive (given yeast in blood),
   cardiogenic (given CHF, frequent ectopy). Improved with resolution of
   bleeding and cardioversion to sinus rhythm. Likely primarily
   cardiogenic in nature.
   - CVVH per above as ultrafiltration will assist in Frank-Starling
   physiology
   - continue vanc/cefepime, plus increased fluconazole 400 mg IV Q24H
   (per ID and pharm)
   - stop flagyl per ID, start bactrim at 560mg IV Q12H
   # Hypoxia:
   Most likely [**1-7**] pulmonary edema and possible PNA as evidenced by CXR.
   Inspiratory effort is also poor at present, which is unexplained, may
   be due to ventilator myopathy. Obesity and hypoventilation likely
   contributors. Needs further diuresis.
   - Continue diuresis
   -Encourage incentive spirometry
   - Continue antibiotics
   - CPAP PRN
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need to revisit intubation
   # LE ulcers: Now growing STAPH AUREUS COAG +, STENOTROPHOMONAS
   (XANTHOMONAS) MALTOPH, and ENTEROBACTER CLOACAE all sensitive to
   bactrim. Vascular has been following, and may recommend surgical
   debridement in future.
   - Continue bactrim 650mg IV Q12 at CVVH doses, will need to readjust
   after CVVH completed
   - continue vanco/cefepime
   - stop flagyl per ID

   - bactrim for stenotrophamonas

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea/pulmonary hypertension, chronic kidney disease, type II diabetes mellitus, severe peripheral vascular disease, and multiple ulcerations. He presented with massive fluid overload and acute-on-chronic renal failure in the setting of atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently in respiratory failure after intubation and has hypotension off pressors. 

Medical Complications:
1. Volume Overload: The patient has fluid overload likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of heart failure. Ultrafiltration is being continued at current rates to allow adequate kidney perfusion while maintaining perfusion to the kidneys.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has improved and is likely primarily cardiogenic in nature. CVVH is being continued to assist in Frank-Starling physiology, and vanc/cefepime antibiotics are being continued along with increased fluconazole.
3. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is most likely due to pulmonary edema and possible pneumonia as evidenced by the chest X-ray. Inspiratory effort is poor, possibly due to ventilator myopathy. Diuresis is being continued, incentive spirometry is encouraged, CPAP is being used as needed, and antibiotics are being continued.
4. Lower Extremity Ulcers: The ulcers are growing STAPH AUREUS COAG +, STEN
